page.title: 02THE WORK OF A GP.
page.content: DR. MACKAY WORKS AT ST. JOHNS AVENUE WHERE THERE IS A SURGERY. HE WORKS WITH THREE OTHER DOCTORS. THE PRACTICE HAS 10,500 PATIENTS, DR. MACKAY HAS 2,800 OF THEM. THE COMMONEST ILLNESSES ARE COUGHS AND COLDS OR INFECTIONS OF THE UPPER RESPIRATORY TRACT. THE COMMONEST MEDICINES USED IN THE SURGERY ARE COUGH MEDICINES AND PAIN KILLING DRUGS. THE MOST SERIOUS DISEASES ARE CANCER AND HEART DISEASES WHICH COULD BE FATAL. THE MOST EXPENSIVE PIECE OF EQUIP- MENT IN THE SURGERY IS AN ELECTRO- CARDIOGRAPH WHICH COST AROUND Â£800. THERE IS 1 TRAINEE DOCTOR AT THE SURGERY AND 3 SECRETARIES. DR. MACKAY GETS TO WORK AT 8.45 A.M. AND STARTS WORK AT 9.00 A.M. HE SEES ABOUT 30 PATIENTS AND THEN MAKES HOME VISITS. IN THE AFTERNOON HE HOLDS ANOTHER SURGERY, FINISHING AT 5.30 P.M.
